review.title: An Empirical Approach for Modeling Fuzzy Geographical Descriptors
review.abstract: We present a novel heuristic approach that defines fuzzy geographical descriptors using data gathered from a survey with human subjects. The participants were asked to provide graphical interpretations of the descriptors `north' and `south' for the Galician region (Spain). Based on these interpretations, our approach builds fuzzy descriptors that are able to compute membership degrees for geographical locations. We evaluated our approach in terms of efficiency and precision. The fuzzy descriptors are meant to be used as the cornerstones of a geographical referring expression generation algorithm that is able to linguistically characterize geographical locations and regions. This work is also part of a general research effort that intends to establish a methodology which reunites the empirical studies traditionally practiced in data-to-text and the use of fuzzy sets to model imprecision and vagueness in words and expressions for text generation purposes.

sections.heading: II. MODELING FUZZY GEOGRAPHICAL DESCRIPTORS
sections.text: Our approach to this task consists of two main elements: a survey that gathers geographical data on users "descriptors (details are explained in paragraph II-A) and a method that builds up its corresponding blurred definitions (the methodology is described in paragraph II-B. As in any D2T system, the method we have followed corresponds to a task to acquire knowledge. This task is designed to capture the fuzziness that arises for given linguistic terms (geographical descriptors in our case) from different interpretations of different users. Although the methodology and our specific approach to modelling blurred geographical descriptors are intended to be general and domain-independent, to support this research we are following a realistic use case. Specifically, our use case focuses on some of the most common geographical descriptors used, for example, in the RoadSafe system [2], [3] descriptors are automatically based on the geographical context of the user in a particular region.

sections.heading: A. Description of the survey
sections.text: The survey was designed with the lessons learned from the preliminary experiment described in [13] in mind. As a result, the survey was prepared to be very intuitive and short, without requiring excessive effort from the participants. sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: We have presented an approach that addresses the problem of defining blurred geographical descriptors that aggregate the interpretation of different users, as part of the broader problem of generating geographical reference expressions. To this end, we have conducted a survey that collects data on the geographical interpretation that users of geographical descriptors such as "north" and "south" undertake in the context of the Galicia region of Spain. Based on this data set, we have proposed a method that builds blurred models of geographical descriptors. As a future work, we intend to conduct the survey described here to collect the interpretation of experienced weather forecasters, which will allow us to obtain deeper insights into the differences between the two subject groups and to examine the possibility of merging them into a single model. We will also examine other alternatives for building the blurred geographical descriptors, such as the paradigm of the actual geographical expressions we will continue to use [22] in order to define the actual geographical concepts [22].
